frameDefinitions: The Cognizers have a similarity (or dissimilarity) in their Opinion.
A physical entity, construed as a point-Sound_source, emits a Sound.
In the Appeal stage of the criminal process the Convict or his or her Representative applies to a higher Court to reverse the Decision of the lower court on certain Grounds. '
The  Speaker expresses through language his wish to get the Addressee to act in some way that will help to bring about events or states described in the Content.
A Communicator conveys a Message to an Addressee; the Topic and Medium of the communication also may be expressed.
In this frame a Speaker asks an Addressee for something, or to carry out some action.
frameExamples: Dr. Gerry and Mr. Pond <t>agree</t> in their impressions.
The defense plans to <t>appeal</t> the court's decision on the grounds that the judge violated Code 81.b .
Mr Smithers always <t>encourages</t> the employees to stay late and work harder.
Let's hope it did n't have time to <t>communicate</t> any of its findings to its overlords.
listRoleDefinitions: This role marks constituents that express the set of <fen>Cognizers</fen> whose similarity of opinion is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Cognizer_1</fen> is the individual characterized by their similarity in opinion to <fen>Cognizer_2</fen>, whose opinion is assumed to be known.  <fen>Cognizer_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Cognizer_2</fen> is the one whose opinion is assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing the opinion of <fen>Cognizer_1</fen>.

This role denotes an implicit question in response to which the <fen>Cognizers</fen> give their <fen>Opinion</fen>s, which are then assessed for their similarity.  The <fen>Question</fen> may concern the identitiy of a particular entity, as in the first example below, or it may be of the yes/no-type, as in the second example below.
A state of affairs believed by the <fen>Cognizers</fen>.
A phenomenon that the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are considering with respect to their <fen>Opinion</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are in agreement or disagreement.
The Place is the general area in which the Cognizers are in agreement or disagreement.

The frame element <fen>Sound_source</fen> is assigned to a constituent referring to a physical entity which emits a sound. Such an entity must have an appropriately complex internal structure such that it can create a sound. For example, a machine or some other thing with moving parts can create sound by itself.

The frame element <fen>Sound</fen> is incorporated in the meaning of the verbs of this frame. Otherwise, this role is assigned to NPs which actually refer to a sound in the presence of the target. This typically occurs when the target is a verb used as a modifier in its <ment>-ing</ment> form, e.g.:
An event in which one or more <fen>Sound_source</fen>s participate and which is accompanied by <fen>Sound</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Noisy_event</fen> occurs.

The location of the <fen>Sound_source</fen>. This role differs from <fen>Location_of_source</fen> only in terms of point of view; the latter role implies a point of view that is not on the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
The <fen>Convict</fen> is the individual convicted of the crime who may make an appeal on her or his behalf.
The <fen>Representative</fen> applies to a higher court on behalf of the <fen>Convict</fen>.
The <fen>Decision</fen> is the ruling handed down by the first court.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which a <fen>Convict</fen> or <fen>Representative</fen> appeals.
The wish for action on the Addressee's part that the Speaker expresses.
The person that the <fen>Speaker</fen> seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
What the communication is about.
The written or spoken material that contains a message that potentially influences the <fen>Addressee</fen> towards the <fen>Content</fen>.
An entity which the <fen>Speaker</fen> believes should participate in the action.
The time at which the lobbying occurs.
The location where the <fen>Speaker</fen> attemtps susaion on an <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
The location where the act of communication occurs.
The <fen>Speaker</fen>, as in other communication frames, is generally an External Argument.
In this frame the <fen>Addressee</fen> can either occur as an NP Object (usually with a following complement clause) or as a PP Complement of verbs or nouns.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the content of the request that can be expressed as a quote, in a finite or non-finite clausal Complement, an NP Object or PP Complement.

The <fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used to transmit the <fen>Message</fen>. The <fen>Medium</fen> is frequently expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>on</ment> or <ment>in</ment>.
The interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the request.
listRoleExamples: I think we see eye to eye <fex>in our ultimate goal</fex>, which is that we want to see a democratic Serbia.
We agree <fex>that babies should not be dropped from helicopters</fex>.
It's going to beep again <fex>in two minutes</fex>.
<fex>He</fex> finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents .
How do you communicate to them <fex>that you really like them</fex> ?
Had someone communicated to the capital <fex>about the flagrant disregard of the religious law</fex> ?
Opinions are usually communicated <fex>over the telephone</fex> and are often given within 24 hours.
<fex>The judge</fex> ordered the plaintiff to return the money.
The child implored <fex>her parents</fex> to let her stay up late.
The parents of the missing child made an appeal <fex>on television</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Ulster Workers' Council (UWC) Strike Committee
Interim Report on the Report of the Independent Commission of Inquiry
the Alliance Party of Northern Ireland
the Offences Against the State (Amendment) Bill
